results.content:
This is a great intro to Vue.js with progressively more challenging projects that you code though.  However, in the projects, much of the work not directly related to Vue has been done, so if you want to be able to competently build these types of apps, it's important that you have other knowledge (e.g. server-side programming with Node) or are willing to do a lot of googling while you take the course. But as a result of this approach, you're able to get a lot of Vue in not a lot of time, so I think it's worth the trade-off. I recommend making sure you understand how each element of the apps work before proceeding to the next project. 

Overall, a great course!

results.content: This is useful as a review course but isn't structured well enough as a proper intro from scratch to VueJS. I would imagine it would be hard to follow along in a way which actually promotes retained learning without having done another more structured course on the basics first. The videos are full of errors which are identified and corrected in real-time, when the presented could be prepared with the correct solution instead of always being surprised after teaching the wrong solution to a new student. However, I am taking this course as a project-focused review of VueJS and for that purpose it is very good.

response.content: Hi Greg, thanks for taking the time to leave a review. I fix errors in the videos in real-time only when I think it demonstrates useful debugging techniques or problems that students are likely to have themselves. To learn to use a framework properly students also need to see methods of identifying and fixing errors, that is an essential part of development. Showing the correct solution every time time is not the best way. If you are getting a lot of value out of this course like you say, it'd be great if you could update your rating to reflect that. Thanks, Anthony.

results.content:
It took me a long time to write a review, but here it is...

There are two significant problems I have discovered while trying to get through the first project, which is preventing me from finishing the rest of the course.

1) Anthony talks too slowly in the course.  I noticed that I can increase the video speed up to 2x without loss of comprehension.

2) The videos are not available for download.  I normally download videos to my laptop for my commute to and from work.  I messaged Anthony about this, and downloading is disabled on Udemy, because he sold the download rights to another publisher that allows the customer to download the videos.   So, don't buy this course from Udemy if you want to download the videos.

In addition, the course syllabus seems well structured, but in the videos, Anthony starts off with premade code already.  As a general beginner, I prefer to code along with the teacher, which means that I would rather have the instructor build most things from scratch in the video.  (Obviously, more advanced coders may not want that, but this course is billed for more novice students.)

On the good side, Anthony seems to know his stuff.  His delivery needs improvement.

results.content:
He makes a really compelling case for using Vuejs and shows some incredible features of the Chrome extension which knocked my socks off, particularly the time-traveling debugger (and I've used AngularJS and Angular2 plugins in the past).

My only quibble is minor: I think he tells, not shows, how jQuery isn't as good. His jQuery code isn't that much longer than the Vue code, so some people might go, "Meh. jQuery's not that bad." One of the major compelling reasons for Vue/Angular/React/etc being superior to jQuery is that the data and state lives in the model in Vue, so DOM manipulation is automatic and declarative. In jQuery, the data and state can be anywhere, so DOM manipulation is awkward and error-prone, limiting the developer and slowly him or her down.

He makes a really compelling case for using Vuejs and shows some incredible features of the Chrome extension which knocked my socks off, particularly the time-traveling debugger (and I've used AngularJS and Angular2 plugins in the past).

My only quibble is minor: I think he tells, not shows, how jQuery isn't as good. His jQuery code isn't that much longer than the Vue code, so some people might go, "Meh. jQuery's not that bad." One of the major compelling reasons for Vue/Angular/React/etc being superior to jQuery is that the data and state lives in the model in Vue, so DOM manipulation is automatic and declarative. In jQuery, the data and state can be anywhere, so DOM manipulation is awkward and error-prone, limiting the developer and slowly him or her down.

results.content:
The bottom-line is: am I effectively learning Vue from this course? Yes!

I'd initially purchased a different Vue course from Udemy, and liked it, but still was still struggling with some key concepts. What I like about this course is that Anthony uses an iterative approach to building the applications--EXACTLY the way it is done in real life: write a bit of code, look to see if it's working (what it's doing), make adjustments, move on to the next logical thing.

While the other course was (perhaps) slightly better scripted (simply meaning that the other course's author was clearly reading and sticking to notes very closely), there was less showing what was just described, making it (sometimes) difficult to envision things--whereas Anthony does a particularly good job of checking back to look at the live site we're building to make sure that what we just wrote was, in fact, doing what we expected.

His teaching style is casual--as if we are simply standing over his shoulder watching how something is created), and it has been very effective and helped me get MUCH clearer on some of Vue's inner workings. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this course!

results.content:
Pace is a good you can use the video tools to speed up or slow down. But the content and the project are useful and real world examples. Very easy to follow along and code side by side for each new learning item.
Well until the second section. I think that the approach was outdated and the set up did not support ES6 and I did not know how to fix. I did finally figure out how to do this and that helped. And the template in a string approach to start instead of single file components was not able to be followed easily.  But I went to project 3 then came back to this project and things fell into place better. And I think for a complete understanding that project 2 and all it's complexity was necessary.
Third section the starting project npm install failed so I could not even work on that one. I submitted a question with the error and got a response within a day or so that I had to install the Git locally on my machine. Then it worked and I was able to complete that project. 
Three good examples with a lot of action and activity.
Only thing I would say is to add a realworld with SQL and a Middleware part to show that part of the application too. You could make a simplified CRUD app with just a bit of Menuing. 
Overall however the best class I've take so far.

results.content:
Just finished the course! This was really well put together and easy to follow. The starting points provided via Github were easy to duplicate and at no point did I have any trouble following along or getting stuck because the environment or actual code differed from the instruction, unlike with many other courses!
The whole thing feels like a mate is sitting down with you and coaching you through your first steps in Vue. Anthony's accent DOES NOT GET OLD and his down to earth explanations really helped me keep focus.
The only part where I lost it and just plain dove into the documentation  was the final chapter on server side rendering. But that's also my main gripe with the Vue ecosystem right now, it seems that there is an excess of environment work required to get these relatively simple features working. I lose interest and inspiration if I have to spend too much time sidetracked on that stuff, so I'll be looking into Nuxt, express-vue and other Vue boilerplates to make life easier.
Thanks for the great course Anthony, definitely got me started on the Vue track!

results.content: A very fine course.  Covers a lot of material and techniques in a very sensibly progressive way, including the event bus design pattern and state management with Vuex.  Intermediate web developers (or those with experience with AngularJS or Angular 2+) will have the most to gain as there isn't too much hand-holding with the concepts here, although new non-trivial concepts are succinctly introduced in their own video before they are then immediately applied in the following videos.

results.content: Anthony covers the material explaining each topic with slides in between exercises to explain the concepts clearly and then immediately see those concepts in action. I feel viewers would improve their technical knowledge as well as learn how to get it done in brief segments that are easy to follow and digest. I would highly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning VueJs and is not familiar with any sort of JavaScript framework and would like to start getting your feet wet, especially if you understand vanilla JavaScript or come from a jQuery background.

I was introduced quickly to interesting information about the relative advantages, use cases, and structure of Vue as well as brief introductions to the course projects -- well done!

The only constructive note I can think of is that *some* background with Node/Express is necessary for the final project.  While I've worked with both extensively I don't recall seeing Node/Express as pre-requisites prior to starting the course.  Granted, those interested in learning Vue without at least some exposure to Node/Express are likely few and possibly learning "out of order", but worth still worth noting in general.

The general format of separate real projects is very nice compared to other courses with arbitrary unrelated examples. Because of this, the content is highly appreciated.
Complaints would be:
-Talking too slow.
-Wasted time on code mistakes. Some of these can be useful, but happens way too frequently, and just feels unrehearsed.
-Code editor does not keep selected file in sync in the file browser. I frequently thought the wrong file was being worked on.
-Use more shortcuts. Instead of talking through 3 steps of "add a div here, give it an ID of X, and class of Y", some editors stub this out for you with a quick "div#x.y".

results.content:
After using Angular 1.3 and experimenting with React, I fell in love with Vue JS.
As I've  used it in two small Web projects, I found the first section  of the course relatively easy, but soon began learning new techniques such as custom directives, event buses and render functions. It's taken me a while to transition away from the DOM scripting approach popularised with jQuery.
I would recommend this course to any Web developer with a good knowledge of Javascript looking the learn the best JS framework for building single page applications.

results.content:
This is a good introduction to Vue.js. It walks you through building an app and you see several basic Vue features in action. As an introductory course, like a written "Getting Started" tutorial, the goal seems to be to expose you to the power and simplicity of Vue without diving too deep. As long as you have a basic understanding of JavaScript, you will benefit from this course. The final web app can serve as a future sandbox for you and there are a few tricks along the way so that alone makes it worth the price.

However, the delivery could be improved.

The instructor often says things twice and sometimes over-demonstrates common problems; for example, slow-loading images. Several times I found myself thinking "Show me how to fix it already!" I actually watched it at 1.5x speed to save some time.

Bouncing back and forth between a browser and a code editor was distracting. I think both could have fit on screen nicely.

There a few text slides where the instructor discusses some features before using them in the app. While I understand the purpose, I couldn't read the slide while the instructor was talking so I just looked them up online later.

Overall, a good introduction.

results.content:
This is a fantastic course, from start to finish.

Anthony provides users with all they need to start working with VUE - and thats the point of this course, You are given the skeleton's of the projects before you get your hands dirty with VUE and any developer who is working in the industry at the moment (at any level, really) will soon find themself thinking in VUE.

My personal advice is to not rush ahead. Often at times I thought I knew better than the course - but I didn't know how to do things the VUE way. Anthony does sometimes go back to change / correct things, but thats exactly what we do in the real world.

Overall , I would highly recommend. I'm 1/3 of the way through this course, and I've been dedicating an hour when I can to completing it. 

At the end, my value (and wage) as a developer should shoot up, and my own personal project  (Originally written in Angular) will be rewritten in Vue.

Thanks Anthony, 
Looking forward to more courses in future.

In this course you gonna go from very simple project to more advanced features from vue js. (vuex, server rendering ....)

Fun course as it is easy to follow, gives you some extra tools that can be useful for the future (moment lib, some node js lib as well).

I saw some bad reviews about this course being to slow , to simple or whatever. Paste of the course might be slow sometime at the beginning but you can always speed up videos or go directly into the section you want so those reviews doesn't make sense to me.

For experienced dev who wants to ramp up very quick on vue i highly recommend the project 2 (cinema) and project 3 especially for the VueX side of it.

IDK if this reviews will help. To resume i'm a professional coder that was total noob on vue and needed to ramp up quickly for professional needs. This course fulfill my needs 100 %.

results.content:
I've built a bunch of web components using Polymer, but lately Polymer 3 does not look encouraging.  My plan is to rebuild these components using Vue and Anthony has given me a great base from which to start.  Another article by Anthony (that I liked very much) relates to building Vue file components using the new es6 modules--so that's just what I did as a challenge for the 3 projects in this course.  It was such a relief not having to deal with loaders, webpack, etc. -- it was just Vue.js, WebStorm, and Anthony's help.  I put the code at my site--https://github.com/deandevl/Vue-JS-2-Developers-Course.  I had fun during the course adding some of my own touches like replacing the simple events array in 'calendar' with a nedb embedded database.
My backend work is heavy into Python--browser based tools for doing data analysis (i.e. numpy, sympy,scipy, etc).  Something that competes with Panda which is very popular; currently the go to .

Again thanks for a great course.  Will be looking for more courses/articles from Anthony in the future.
God bless-Rick Dean

results.content:
This was a great course!. Anthony is very knowledgable about Vue and does a great job explaining the concepts and then walking you through implementing them in non-trivial example applications.  


As pointed out by other reviews he does talk slow in his videos since they are for beginners or people who are relatively new to web/front-end development. I'm pretty comfortable with JavaScript and other front end frameworks like React, Angular 2, and Aurelia so I just changed the video speed to 2x and any frustration at the speed of the teaching was gone.  


Now that I've gone completed this course I feel like I have a strong understanding of the fundamentals of Vue. One thing I was really wanting out of a Vue course was an overview of state management as I've used ngrx/stores in Angular 2 projects and I wanted to see the Vue way. Using Vuex in the third sample project gave me all of the knowledge I need to feel comfortable moving forward using Vue/Vuex in future production applications.  


If you're looking for a comprehensive overview of Vue and want to get up and running with another great front-end framework I would highly recommend this course.

response.content: Thanks Craig for taking the time to write this great review.

results.content: This is a very good introductory course on vue.js. The instructor presents information clearly and effectively, and he covers a lot of ground. The projects were interesting and useful examples of building applications with vue. I would have rated the course higher, but I think there is content missing that I would consider to be essential to learning vue. There is no material on working with forms and validating data, and the course includes no content on security topics like authentication and cross-site request forgery. The content on server-side rendering was difficult to follow and was not personally useful. Overall a good course.
